author: Victor Ferreira
title: Ontario high school teacher who pushed anti-vaccination views found guilty of professional misconduct
text:
An Ontario teacher stormed out of his tribunal hearing after he was found guilty of professional misconduct for shouting at students preparing to get inoculated, arguing that vaccines for polio and diphtheria could cause death.
Timothy Sullivan, a high school teacher from Waterford, Ont., also confronted the nurses administering the vaccines at a school clinic, a three-person panel heard at an Ontario Teachers college tribunal on Wednesday. He accused them of withholding information from students about the possible side effects.
Sullivan, who represented himself during the two-day hearing, was found guilty of committing professional misconduct because he acted in a disgraceful, dishonourable and unprofessional manner during the incident.
But the science teacher with the Grand Erie School Board argued he acted like a “role model” on March 9, 2015. He compared his warnings about potential side effects to teaching students what could happen if they ingest dangerous chemicals in his class.
Related Robert Fulford: Anti-vaxxers are winning as ignorance and pseudo-science vanquish intelligence Lawrence Solomon: How vaccine safety turned into one of Trump’s first presidential priorities A vaccine made my baby stop breathing. But I still believe in vaccination Sullivan was not required to testify, but he chose to defend himself by calling what was taking place at the clinic “assault and batter.”
“As a role model you should be informing another person there are inherent dangers of a particular practice,” Sullivan said. “Canadians are unaware of the serious side effects of vaccines.”
Sullivan quickly left the tribunal when college lawyer Christine Wadsworth made her recommendation on the penalties he’d face. As he ran through the streets of downtown Toronto, Sullivan said he no longer needed to remain at the tribunal and yelled that Wadsworth compared his case to sexual misconduct when making a suggestion about the penalty.
The Ontario College of Teachers is seeking a one-month suspension of Sullivan’s teaching licence and a reprimand. After being found guilty, Sullivan may also have to enrol in courses on professional ethics and anger management within 90 days.
